Yes, geisha undergo extensive training in dance as it is an important part of their performance art. Geisha dances are traditional Japanese dances that are performed to tell a story or convey a specific emotion or mood. Geisha dancers use their bodies to communicate the story or emotion they want to convey, with the music of the shamisen and other instruments supporting and complementing their movements.

Geisha begin their dance training at a young age, usually around the age of 6 or 7, and may continue their training for many years. Their training focuses on learning the specific movements, gestures, and expressions that are appropriate for each dance. In addition to learning choreography, geisha dancers also learn about the history and cultural significance of each dance.

Geisha dances are typically very fluid and graceful, with intricate footwork and delicate movements of the hands and fingers. The dances are often complex and may incorporate a range of emotions, from joy and celebration to sadness and melancholy. In addition to their technical skill, geisha dancers must also be attuned to the emotional and cultural context of each dance to successfully convey the intended mood or message to their audience.

Overall, dance is a crucial aspect of the geisha tradition, and geisha dancers undergo years of rigorous training to perfect their art. The beauty and grace of geisha dances continue to be an enduring symbol of Japanese culture and tradition.
